stem: The nurse is caring for a client diagnosed with schizophrenia who is exhibiting increased agitation, disorganized thoughts, and auditory hallucinations. Based on the EHR data, what actions are most important for the nurse to take next? For each action, indicate the potential condition and parameter to monitor.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
2024-07-26 14:00: Nurse S. Rodriguez reporting on Mr. James T., DOB 1990-03-15. Admitted 07/24 for acute exacerbation of schizophrenia. Currently exhibiting increased agitation, pacing, and talking to self. States he hears voices telling him he is in danger. 

2024-07-26 14:15: Noted patient refusing lunch, stating food is poisoned. Offered alternative meal, which was also refused. Attempted redirection unsuccessful. 

2024-07-26 14:30: Administered Olanzapine 10mg PO as per PRN order for agitation. Monitored patient for side effects. 

2024-07-26 15:00: Patient continues to exhibit signs of agitation, though slightly less intense. Remains guarded and suspicious. Encouraged patient to attend group therapy session, patient refused.

2024-07-26 15:30: Ongoing monitoring of patient's mental status and vital signs. Will continue to reassess and implement de-escalation techniques as needed.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Appears agitated, pacing. 
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI. 
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. 
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. 
Neurological: Alert but disoriented to time and place. 
Psychiatric: Anxious, guarded, exhibiting paranoid ideations. Responding to internal stimuli.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Monitor mental status q shift.
  • Administer Olanzapine 10mg PO PRN for agitation.
  • Encourage participation in group therapy.
  • Provide a safe and structured environment.
  • Assess for suicidal/homicidal ideation.

parameters.text: Monitor for escalating agitation and aggression.

rationale.correct: Implementing suicide precautions is crucial due to the client's expressed auditory hallucinations suggesting danger and increased agitation, which are risk factors for self-harm. Administering PRN haloperidol IM is appropriate to manage acute agitation and psychotic symptoms that pose an immediate threat. Monitoring for escalating agitation and aggression is essential to proactively manage the client's behavior and prevent harm to self or others. Assessing for command hallucinations is vital to determine the content of the hallucinations and whether they are instructing the client to harm themselves.
rationale.incorrect: Encouraging participation in recreational activities is not the priority when the client is acutely agitated and experiencing psychotic symptoms. While reality orientation can be helpful, it's less effective during acute psychosis and may increase agitation. Monitoring for medication side effects and assessing the client's sleep pattern are important aspects of care but are not the priority actions in this acute situation focused on safety.

clinicalPearls: In acute psychosis, prioritize safety and symptom management over long-term therapeutic interventions.
PRN medications should be administered judiciously, with careful monitoring of the client's response and side effects.
Command hallucinations require immediate assessment and intervention to prevent harm.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting interventions aimed at long-term therapy (e.g., reality orientation, recreational activities) instead of addressing the immediate risk of harm.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the immediacy of the threat and the client's current mental state. Focus on safety and symptom management during acute episodes.

mnemonic.title: SAFETY FIRST
